properties.name: Cameroon
properties.author: Martine Tchitchihe (University of Pennsylvania)
properties.description: Cameroon is a culturally diverse country located in central Africa, with over 250 ethnic groups and more than 200 languages spoken. Pre-colonial Cameroon thus comprised a complex system of kingdoms and societies.  Following colonization by German, French, and British powers, the country gained independence in 1960; it continues to struggle with political instability and economic challenges. The rich cultural heritage of Cameroon finds expression through many media, including music, dance, and traditional crafts; established institutions now seek to preserve and promote such heritage while encouraging contemporary arts and cultural expressions in more contemporary idioms. This chapter will trace the development of Cameroonian nationalism, focusing on the contributions of Cameroonian writers and cultural institutions and emphasizing the impact of schooling. Of especially compelling interest in this story is the life and legacy of Ibrahim Njoya (1875-1933), who ruled as monarch in Bamu, a territory in western Cameroon. Nyoja’s dynasty traced its roots back many centuries, and Nyoja made a series of attempts to develop a writing system, influenced by Arabic and featuring pictographic script. A long history of the Bamu kingdom was commissioned, and Nyoja went on to develop a new language for his court, Shümom, which became the official language of record; schools were established to teach it. Such innovations flourished under German colonial patronage, but did not survive the transition to French colonial rule. Njoya was exiled from his own kingdom to the Cameroonian capital Yaoundé in 1931, and died two years later. As suggested by Patrice Ngangang’s novel Mount Pleasant (2011), Njoya is a complex and contradictory figure who, while operating working within strict parameters of colonial control, nonetheless enlarged the horizons of Cameroonian aspirational identity.

properties.name: Jamaica
properties.author: Nadi Edwards (Norval Edwards, PhD, The University of the West Indies, Mona Campus)
properties.description: This chapter examines how certain shibboleths pertaining to postcolonial representations of nation, history, and collective identity are confounded in selected Jamaican fiction and popular musical discourses. Using Victor Stafford Reid’s New Day (1949) as a point of departure, I argue that this novel, published five years after the granting of Universal Adult Suffrage, is strikingly emblematic of the anticolonial turn and the retrieval of a history of rebellion that is used to legitimized the nationalist politics of the 1940s and 1950s. New Day’s epic template is echoed to some extent in John Hearne’s Voices Under the Window (1955), and Neville Dawes’ The Last Enchantment (1960) and Interim (1978), but it is cunningly revised by Margaret Cezair Thompson’s The True History of Paradise (1999), a novel which revisits the premises of New Day to replace the paternal genealogies and narrative authority of Reid’s oracular narrator, John Campbell, with an interwoven and intricate web of imbricated histories, narrators, and temporalities that confound the nationalist epic ambitions of the earlier text. Cezair Thompson ‘s text-- with its spectral, haunting complication of nation, history, identity, place, and belonging-- engenders an ontological disruption of the postcolonial epic project. In foregrounding the affective elements of desire, familial relationships, and the psychological complexities of human and social relationships, Cezair Thompson effectively establishes a template for confounding the attempt to write a cohesive epic narrative of Jamaican history, a template which is reiterated in Erna Brodber’s Nothing’s Mat (2014) and Curdella Forbes A Tall History of Sugar (2019), two novels which foreground a filial poetics and politics of affect in articulating Jamaican public and private histories from the post-emancipation period to the present. The woman-centric epic revisioning of New Day in the fictions of Cezair Thompson, Brodber, and Forbes ultimately share elective affinities with the dread histories evoked in reggae songs and the anti-epic dystopian narratives in Marlon James’ A Brief History of Seven Killings (2014).

properties.name: Iraq
properties.author: Muhsin Jassim Al-Musawi (Colombia University)
properties.caption: the 3600-year old 'Gilgamesh Dream Tablet,' taken from Iraq in 1991 and restored in 2021
properties.description: The Epic of Gilgamesh is the earliest inscribed epic in the history of mankind. Gilgamesh is mentioned in Sumerian poems, and the epic culminates what was probably a long literary tradition before being put into inscribed tablet form.  A finished text of heroic pursuits and trials, it explores the human search for the unlimited, the vast, and the immortal. It also explores the thin border line between nature and culture, and details first encounters with a bartender, a harlot, Sidori, who tames forces of nature through her adept temptations.  It unfolds in a worldwide  arena where  humans and demigods roam the universe: Ishtar ( Astarte), Gilgamesh, Dumzi, Enkidu, Shamash, Sidori, Utnapishtim, Humbaba, and some others.The challenge of death is the backbone of the epic, with many subplots and  thematic complications. Can Gilgamesh conquer death? The epic has been a driving force all over the world, but especially in Iraq: 'He, who saw it all', a key phrase, recurs in poetry, epics, cultural forms. 1950s modernist poetry takes its lead from the legends of Damuzi and Ishtar and the search for rebirth. The same driving force in nationalism reckons with the possibile rebirth of an Arab nation. The literary scene since the mid-40s abounds with this regenerative motif. James Frazer's Golden Bough, that devotes a chapter to Mesopotamian mythology, and that was translated later by Jabra Ibrahim Jabra, is usually referenced as a source book. Poets devote poems to one character or another. The late Iraqi poet Sa'di Yusuf devotes one to Sidori. Some playwrights and short story writers impose a national theme when speaking of possible hope for Gilgamesh, and the late short story writer Khudayyor Abd al-Amir writes, ‘Is there a Hope for Gilgamesh?’ The epic thus dwells in the mind of writers and poets as long as such questionings and searchings endure. Crash courses are given, and Gilgamesh rarely disappears from any course on Iraq.

properties.name: Indonesia
properties.author: Chris GoGwilt (Fordham University)
properties.description: Pramoedya Ananta Toer’s Buru quartet of novels succeeded, against all the odds, in telling the story of Indonesia’s formation, reimagining the history of a new nation almost completely destroyed in the events of 1965 that toppled Sukarno, killed thousands of Indonesians, and exiled its most celebrated author to the remote Buru island prison camps where he composed the now-internationally acclaimed work. Its epic scope sets the model by which contemporary Indonesian historians, political activists, and imaginative writers have continued to measure the coordinates of the Indonesian nation. Through its influence on the famous thesis of Benedict Anderson’s Imagined Communities, Pramoedya’s work has also shaped contemporary discussions of ‘the origin and the spread of nationalism.’ This chapter will discuss how Pramoedya’s vision of Indonesian nationalism, and the grand narrative ‘epic’ form that shapes it, emerged from the adverse conditions of the Buru prison camp where Pramoedya composed not only the Buru quartet, but a series of other epic historical narratives tracing the roots of Indonesian nationalism back through the 16th century (with Arus Balik) and the 13th century (with Arok Dedes). It will consider, too, how Pramoedya’s work has led to a series of epic-scale literary works at the beginning of the 21st century (notably, Eka Kurniawan’s Beauty is a Wound). To understand the scope of Pramoedya’s influence both within Indonesia and globally, the chapter will also consider the paradox that, going back to the earliest of Pramoedya’s writings, the epic scale and grand narrative historical ambitions of his work are premised on a profoundly anti-epic, fragmentary, and satirically anti-belle-lettristic form. Pitched against traditional Javanese conceptions of ancestry and the passing down of indigenized Javanese versions of the Mahabharata and Ramayana, this dissident critique of epic literary form underpins the distinctively Indonesian style of Pramoedya’s work in decolonizing tradition.

properties.name: Cambodia
properties.author: Roger Nelson (Nanyang Technical University, Singapore) & Ashley Thompson (SOAS, London)
properties.caption: Koh Ker temple ensemble, National Museum
properties.description: The National Museum of Phnom Penh turned the closing of national borders and museum doors during the global pandemic to its advantage. Unhindered by visitors, museum staff re-conceived the display of a monumental 10th-century statuary ensemble of figures from the Mahabharata which had been looted under cover of war and returned piecemeal to Cambodia from prestigious Western art institutions over the previous decade.  In the new museum staging of the original temple staging, the sculptures are no longer made to participate in the story of historical evolution matching artistic styles with sovereign reigns told room-by-room since the museum’s early 20th-century foundation; museum visitors no longer study each piece frontally and individually for its craftsmanship.  Now, seen to be engaging with each other and turning their backs to viewers, they bring the Mahabharata to life. The Mahabharata and the Ramayana were well known in ancient Cambodia, with scenes from both Sanskrit epics abundantly referenced in sculpture and epigraphic literature always appearing to endow the historically conditioned locality with a vision of itself as transcending time and space. By the 16th-17th centuries, a Khmer-language verse version of the Ramayana staged the hero Rama as a Buddha-to-be. Another of the earliest literary compositions in Khmer narrates the Ramayana reliefs sculpted on the walls of the epic 12th-century temple of Angkor Wat.  In the early 20th century the Ramayana was painted on the enclosure walls of Phnom Penh’s Royal Palace Temple of the Emerald Buddha. The Ramayana continues to be staged in contemporary art and dance dramas —many conceived with activist ambitions.  In image and word, theatre and ritual, the Khmer Ramayana has variously underpinned the identity of monarch, court and state. It also bore the seed of critique of power.  The Mahabharata, on the other hand, seems to have been all but forgotten after Angkor. Until now, perhaps.

properties.name: Haiti
properties.author: Charles Forsdick (Liverpool)
properties.caption: ‘Desalines - Huyes del valor francés, pero matando blancos’, in Dubroca, Vida de J. J. Dessalines, gefe de los negros de Santo Domingo (1806)
properties.description: The nation-building narratives of Haiti draw heavily on accounts of the country’s revolution against enslavement and its war for independence (1791-1804). While subsequent events, such as resistance to the U.S. occupation of 1915-34, have been adopted for these purposes, they lack the power and reach of stories associated with the revolutionary leaders, Toussaint Louverture, Jean-Jacques Dessalines and Henry Christophe. Among these, it is perhaps Louverture who has achieved the greatest prominence, although his visibility is more significant outside Haiti than within. In Haiti itself, Louverture is the precursor, but Dessalines himself the liberator central to the construction of a national epic. Dessalines joined the vodou pantheon as a lwa, the national anthem – ‘La Dessalinienne’ – was written in his honour, and Dessalinians still act as the adversaries of Louverturians in Haitian political life. This contribution considers the role of these founding figures in Haiti’s national epic, but focuses in particular on the role of Dessalines. It analyses the ambiguities associated with Haiti’s founding leader, but contrasts external perceptions of Dessalines (often derogatory and highly racialized in literary refigurings from early 1800s onwards) with his representation in Haiti itself. To this end, I will draw on material from mid-nineteenth-century Haitian historiography to L’Haitiade by Gragnon-Lacoste, and also consider how Dessalines has been systematically instrumentalized in political and commemorative contexts (including contemporary Haiti).  An indication of this enduring mythologisation within the national narrative is the recent creation of Amwari by Karl Heins Desroches, a Dessalinian comic-book hero who acts as saviour of the country as it faces multiple current crises. Finally, the study considers alternative literary accounts – recognizing more fully the role of the people, or countering the more gendered aspects of the dominant narratives – that have existed for a number of years but are attracting increasing attention in the 21st century.

properties.name: Democratic Republic of Congo
properties.author: Nancy Rose Hunt (University of Florida)
properties.caption: Ballet Lianja Epic, DR Congo, Patrimonie PanAfrica Heritage Centre
properties.description: My contribution will investigate various publications, uses, and performances of the Lianja epic, a regional epic of Congo’s Lomongo speakers. It was only partially ever a national epic within the huge ex-Belgian colony that became postcolonial Congo (today DR Congo). It was probably long-established in the region, dating perhaps to the 18th century or earlier. Flemish colonial missionaries were keen to represent it as a “national’ epic for their imagined ‘nation’ of diverse Lomongo peoples, among whom they worked. They published several scholarly, usually bi-lingual, versions, from the 1920s to the 1970s. From the 1960s, Lianja became the basis of some of the first national theatrical performances, traveling internationally and beyond the capital. As new digital media such as FaceBook came into play in the 1990s, Lianja received new attention, reach, and meanings. There are also children’s book versions. The colonial missionary texts were in Dutch-Lomongo or French-Lomongo, and these scholarly versions assembled and edited by Flemish priests were partially Catholic in interpretation. Some FaceBook versions suggest more risqué meanings and elaborations. This epic from central Africa knew diverse audiences with national conceits and theatrical media. It is important, therefore, to be careful with the word ‘national.’ We should investigate how a regional epic, of which there were several in Congo, may take on new meanings and purposes when played out on a national scale in times of decolonization, when theatrical stories met new needs and scales for performing authenticity and pride. The implications of new media are also important, especially those that became readily available to most anybody within Congo’s wide diaspora since the late 1980s. Throughout this long and complex history, and across many terrains of 'Congo', new actors and audiences have remade the purposes, meanings, and uses of this ancient set of stories about wealth, reproduction, fame, crisis, and resolution.

properties.name: Palestine
properties.author: Ahmad Almallah (University of Pennsylvania)
properties.caption: Handhalah on wall in Bilin (Palobserver, Wiki Commons, 2011); Kanafani on wall at Bethlehem (AA)
properties.description: Palestine is not a myth, and does not adopt a myth other than itself. The poet Mahmoud Darwish made a metaphor of it, connecting it to the loss of Eden, or of Andalusia, while also proposing the simple formula for the name's resonance, political and poetical: ‘Its name was Palestine/Its name has become Palestine.’ Palestine thus connects to the mythical world as a place of loss, but also as a future space, to be gained. It is a point in time, extending back to its past, under siege and occupation in the present, and a homeland, as in the Arabic watan, to be liberated in the future. Here comes the real creator of this formula, the journalist and novelist Ghassan Kanafani. His writings urge Palestinians not to wallow in mythic nostalgia, but rather to use memory of the place as a point of rooting the right of return. To him, action defeats nostalgia. For Palestinian refugees, Kanafani remains the essential Palestinian, joined in that unwavering position by cartoonist Naji al-Ali. His drawing of Handhalah, the child who will not grow up until he returns to Palestine, became as close as it gets to the mythical in its use. Handhalah in the drawing of al-Ali stands with his back to us somewhere on the canvas of represented events only to witness injustice. Handhalah, the child witness, keeps being recreated on walls in Palestine, and wherever Palestinians reside, especially in refugee camps around the world. Both Kanafani and Ali stand firm against mythologizing Palestine as ‘a lost Eden.’ Palestine through these artists comes to represent a struggle for justice, a national-native cause, claiming a right to a native-land. Thus, I argue that Palestine stands in opposition to a national epic; its natives have been uprooted from the real, and their absurd existence now is the only thing resembling myth.

properties.name: Ambazonia
properties.author: Patrice Nganang (Stony Brook University)
properties.caption: Mancho Bibixy, now jailed, addressing his Anglophone community in November 2016.
properties.description: The Gulf of Guinea is oil rich, but riddled with conflicts. As an entry point to the triangular slave trade, it features in the Narrative of Olaudah Equiano, and then in multiple colonial treatises and fictions that informed colonialism. Since the 1960s which brought the independence of most African nations, it has been torn between two grand ideas: independence, and with it the magnificence of nation-building, or secession. Central to both options is the question of minorities, and their relation to the nation. In the Gulf of Guinea, ‘Ambazonia’ is the newest formulation of the idea of secession, following the ‘Biafra’ idea (and its attendant literature). ‘Ambazonia,’ designating the English-speaking minority of Cameroon, figures metaphorically how minorities are regarded (or not), in postcolonial African nations as they set in motion the process of birthing a new nation. The term was coined in Revolution in Ambazonia (1984), a pamphlet written in prison by Fongum Gorji-Dinka (then head of the Cameroon Bar Association), a text central to Cameroonian Anglophone nationalism. Intellectual, legal, and then political debate has been transformed into a militarily contested battlefield, involving genocide. My chapter will trace the birth of an English-speaking literature in Cameroon, not as a pendant to French-speaking Cameroonian literature, but as articulating a specific idea of being Anglophone, and of minoritarian status in Africa. It will consider the literary formulation of a way of life that, starting in 2017, transformed into war, while also producing one of the most important literary figures of the younger generation – Imbolo Mbue.

properties.name: Nicaragua
properties.author: Tatiana Argüello (Texas Christian University) & Andrew Ryder (Texas Christian University)
properties.caption: 'El Güegüense' by Leoncio Sáenz
properties.description: Of the Central American nations, Nicaragua has the most widely known national literature, particularly in poetry. The great Nicaraguan poet, Rubén Darío, tends to be interpreted as a cosmopolitan modernist, but he is also a national figure who has served different political purposes-- either for condemning US expansionism, in poems such as ‘To Roosevelt,’ or calling for a political union among nations, in poems such as ‘The Optimist's Salutation.’ From the avant-garde movement, Pablo Antonio Cuadra’s poems reflect on mestizo Nicaraguan identity, rescuing rural life and the Indigenous past with an idealistic lens. The continuing development of the poetry and literature of national liberation took place alongside the resistance to the American-supported dictatorship of the Somoza family and in the aftermath of the victory of the Revolution of 1979. The revolutionary period consolidated a sense of common identity among Nicaraguan authors of poetry and fiction, such as Gioconda Belli, Ernesto Cardenal and Sergio Ramírez, who directly participated in the new government. At this time, distinctly Nicaraguan literary creativity often included themes of Christian revelation, popular egalitarianism, decolonization, international socialist idealism, women’s liberation, and multiracial consciousness. Regarding this latter, Carlos Rigby is the great Afro-descendant poet who brought the Atlantic Coast region into national discourse, exclaiming in his poem ‘I am NiCaribbean.’ However, the end of the revolutionary period in 1990 led to a widespread sense of pessimism and disenchantment. The present moment is characterized by confusion and contentiousness; while the current regime claims to continue and re-invigorate the goals of the revolution, many of the initial progenitors of the revolution view it as betraying those values. Sergio Ramírez’s novel, Tongolele no sabía bailar (2021), is the most internationally known contemporary attempt to express the failure of the Nicaraguan revolutionary process and to re-invigorate a sense of democratic possibility.

properties.name: Barbados
properties.author: J. Dillon Brown (Washington University in St Louis)
properties.description: Barbados is the only Caribbean island to have been subjected to unbroken English rule from the first moment of its colonization.  This unusually stable political relationship, stretching from 1627 to flag independence in 1966, led to Barbados thinking of itself, often proudly, as ‘Little England,’ a self-identification that became increasingly fraught as anti-colonial nationalist sentiment gained momentum beginning in the 1930s.  Barbados also played a key role in the mid-century West Indies Federation (1958-1962), providing the first and only Prime Minister, Grantley Adams, for that short-lived experiment in regional-national political autonomy.  Caught thus between admiration for and abhorrence of the consequences of English rule, and between a sense of regional solidarity and its own individual island pride, Barbados represents a complex case study of national identity formation forged amidst the pressures of race, class, and shifting colonial power.  The complexity of narrating the Barbadian nation registers in the widely divergent strategies adopted by some of the island’s most internationally prominent authors, including Kamau Brathwaite, Austin Clarke, and George Lamming.  If Brathwaite strove to root island identity in the reconstitution of transatlantic links with Africa, Clarke turned to a corrosive exilic satire of colonial life, while Lamming sought to model an open-ended, but tortuously negotiated unity of liberated individual consciousnesses. More contemporary cultural phenomena like popular music and television – always under the shadow of the United States’ regional hegemony – can also be seen to register the difficulties and paradoxes that continue to inflect efforts to articulate a recognizably Bajan identity amidst the clashing, inter-imperial currents that structure the history and culture of this small, but passionately self-sovereign island nation.

properties.name: Cape Verde
properties.author: Simone Caputo Gomes (Universidade de São Paulo (USP), Brazil)
properties.description: Cape Verde, a small insular country of Sub-Saharan Africa, has seen literary production of singularly epic pedigree, featuring texts which emerge prior to the colony's independence from Portugal in 1975, and then postcolonial texts that carry forward the Cape Verdean national narrative. Before 1975, two authors stood out before prolonging their achievement post-independence: Corsino Fortes (1933-2015), who published Pão & fonema in 1974, followed by Árvore & tambor (1986) and Pedras de sol & substância (2001); and the neurosurgeon and epical poet Timóteo Tio Tiofe (heteronym of João Manuel Varela, neurosurgeon, writer, and epical poet, 1937-2007). The mosaic of this epic production also sees Kaká Barboza, Mário Lúcio Sousa, Nzé di Sant'y Águ (pseudo-heteronym of José Luís Hopffer Almada), Danny Spínola and José Luiz Tavares, engaged in reconstruction exercises, employing diverse aesthetic effects to evoke the genesis of the islands and the ruins of a history still insufficiently narrated. The poets re-enact, through memory, the drama of a paradise surrounded by Atlantic waters, but buffeted by prolonged droughts, a situation aggravated by two factors: the agricultural tradition inherited from the Portuguese colonizer and neglect by the colonial administration over 500 years, expanding tragic-telluric dimensions into historical tragedy. My account focusses chiefly on the great Cape Verdean epic, told both in Portuguese and native language: the poetic trilogy of Corsino Fortes, collected as A cabeça calva de deus (2001). This work, fundamental in representing the colony's struggle for freedom in the midst of the Salazar dictatorship, its national construction and consolidation, covers three key moments in Cape Verdean history: pre-independence, the ‘zero hour’ (i.e., independence), and post-independence. This work, honoring the Cape Verdean people, their heroes and cultural foundations, provides an excellent basis for understanding the reverberations of nationalism in Cape Verdean literature within the archipelago and in its diaspora.

properties.name: Russia
properties.author: Ilya Vinitsky (Princeton University)
properties.caption: Viktor Mikhaylovich Vasnetsov (1848-1926), The Field of Igor's battle with the Polovtsy
properties.description: Searching for a national epic was a national sport from the late 18th century through the Soviet period. Major ideological groups (neoclassicists and romantics, Slavophiles and Westernizers; realist, modernist, and Soviet literary critics) and institutions (the Russian Academy, court, masonic and political societies, ‘thick’ journals, state agencies) obsessively investigated issues of national identity and mission, of Russia versus the West, and of forming a national literary canon (that would influence the world). There were several attempts to create a Russian national epic in the 18th century, from Mikhailo Lomonosov’s narrative poem Peter the Great to Mikhail Kheraskov’s neoclassical allegorical epics Rossiada (1779) and Vladimir Reborn (1785). The medieval epic poem known as The Lay of Igor’s Campaign was discovered in 1795, but then lost to the Great Fire of Moscow in 1812. As the only literary text predating the Mongol invasions, this short tale of questionable authenticity became foundational for national culture, with numerous echoes in Russian Romantic poetry culminating in Alexander Borodin’s opera, Prince Igor. In the earlier 19th century, candidates for national epic status included Pushkin’s ‘novel in verse’ Eugene Onegin (1823 – 1831), called ‘an encyclopedia of Russian life,’ and Nikolai Gogol’s ‘narrative poem in prose’ Dead Souls (1841), considered by Russian Slavophiles as a national equivalent of Homer’s epics. The age of Great Reforms (1860s-70s) triggered realist experiments in creating the national epic novel, most notably with Leo Tolstoy’s War and Peace. Modernist epics include Andrei Bely’s symbolist novel Petersburg (1913), with its theosophical background expanding the work's‘historical’ dimensions. The early Soviet period brings Aleksei Tolstoy's The Road to Calvary (1918-1928), and Mikhail Sholokhov’s Quiet Flows the Don (1928–1940), followed after World War II by Boris Pasternak’s Doctor Zhivago (1957) and Vasilii Grossman’s Life and Fate (1960-1980); more ironically, we have Venedikt Yerofeev’s ‘alcoholic odyssey’ Moscow to the End of the Line (1973).

properties.name: Uruguay
properties.author: Gustavo San Román (University of St Andrews)
properties.caption: Juan Manuel Blanes, Resurgimento de la Patria (1888)
properties.description: The obvious candidate for a Uruguayan national epic is Juan Zorrilla de San Martín and his Tabaré (1888), a narrative poem about a tragic Charrúa hero who dies to make way for a future Hispanic nation. This became the author’s most famous contribution to late-19th--century endeavours by intellectuals to validate a country that had been created by outside forces in 1828. Until the 1960s the work occupied a privileged place in school syllabi, and although its treatment of the Indians has led to controversy in recent decades, its ambiguity and semantic richness account for its continuing resonance. The second part of our 'Uruguay' chapter will engage with a novel whose powerful homage to the nation’s achievements is enhanced by the fact that it was composed by a foreigner. W. H. Hudson (1841-1922) was an Argentinian best known for writing about the nature of his adoptive England. However, his first publication, The Purple Land that England Lost (1885), takes place in neither of his homelands, both failing to satisfy him at the time, but in the Banda Oriental, the traditional appellation for Uruguay. The trigger for the story is the elopement of Englishman Richard Lamb and his new wife Paquita from Buenos Aires to Montevideo, following paternal displeasure. The protagonist’s judgment of his host country undergoes a radical transformation, from irate disapproval to unreserved exaltation, as he applauds the Orientales’ grassroots democracy and their attachment to the natural world-- two qualities praised by an author then living in poverty in an unwelcoming and class-conscious London. The two works, published within three years of each other at a time when the enterprise of the nation needed buttressing, provide complementary heroic tales for a young and still insecure Uruguay.

properties.name: Lebanon
properties.author: Mouannes Hojairi (The American University in Cairo)
properties.caption: Arch of Hadrian at the Al-Bass Tyre Necropolis
properties.description: This chapter will address tensions over a national myth of origin in Lebanese historiography, which in turn informed the struggle over what constitutes a national epic. Lebanese church historians and secular lay historians advanced competing origin stories for the Lebanese nation; these subsequently contributed to the rise of a contested national identity in the sectarian landscape of modern Lebanon. In a country initially conceived as a homeland for a specific Christian community, the Maronites, but currently inhabited by numerous others, the concept of a national epic is naturally fraught with tensions and contradictions. How, then, to locate an epic that might engender a sense of unified national identity in a divided and sectarian national culture? Among the origin stories favored by secular nationalist historians of the early 20th century, ancient Phoenicia is exceptionally favored, and is omnipresent in public spaces in Lebanon. This is the state-sponsored myth chosen for history instruction in public education, figuring prominently on national monuments as well as the national currency. Found in history books written by nationalist historians such as Yusif al-Sawda, it has inspired the poems of Sa‘id ‘Aql’s in Sagesse de Phenicie.  Yet these same histories allude to another origin story, one that appeared much earlier in the writings of Maronite Church historians of the 19th century, such as Nicolas Murad’s Notice historique sur l’origine de la nation Maronite. Such histories link the origins of the Maronite community specifically to a group called the Mardaites, thereby establishing a church-sponsored origin story.    This chapter will address the struggle between these competing myths of origin to achieve the status of national epic in the divisive national narratives of Lebanon; how does a church-adopted ‘Mardaite’ myth compete with, yet sometimes inform, a secular ‘Pheonecian’ myth of origin for modern Lebanon?

properties.name: Ireland
properties.author: Nessa Cronin (Centre for Irish Studies, NUI Galway, Ireland)
properties.caption: Panel inset from ‘Threading the Táin’ tapestry series. The Táin Arts Centre, Dundalk, Co. Louth. 2022.
properties.description: The creation and invention of a nation is often founded on myth, legend, and folklore. One narrative central to the making of the Irish national imagination is the saga of Táin Bó Cuailgne (The Cattle Raid of Cooley). Set in a pagan heroic age, this foundational story has retained a constant presence in the Irish cultural imagination, giving rise to wider questions as to how epic narratives are employed as rhetorical devices and deployed to give voice to other kinds of historical realities in the present. Originating from oral tradition, the Táin was preserved in Old and Middle Irish manuscripts and came back into prominence in the late 19th century during the Irish Cultural Revival period. It has been revised and revived in various English and Irish language versions since that time. This chapter explores the idea of the epic in the creation of Ireland, focusing on the continuing cultural resonance of the Táin Bó Cuailgne in Ireland today. Particular emphasis will be placed on the work of Thomas Kinsella, who brought the work to a wider Irish public with his modern translation in 1969. The chapter also discusses Threading the Táin, a collective stitch tapestry project that employed teams of community sewers from Roscommon, Longford, Westmeath, Meath and Louth (each of the five counties mentioned in the saga), with sewing complemented by techniques including appliqué, embroidery, quilting, and hand-dyeing. Táin Bó Cuailgne has also been a constant presence in the repertoire of Irish children’s literature, the latest version being the reproduction of the tale in graphic novel form in 2006 produced by the Cartoon Saloon.

properties.name: Bangladesh
properties.author: Zakir Hossain Raju (Independent University, Bangladesh)
properties.description: This eastern part of Bengal province under British India (1757-1947) became independent Bangladesh in 1971 through a national war of liberation. The Bengal delta was largely isolated from other parts of South Asia until the mid-16th century; Bengal was annexed as a province under the Delhi-based Mughal empire in 1574, and Dhaka made its capital in 1610. Following the 1947 partition, East Bengal became East Pakistan for next 23 years and then Bangladesh in 1971. How then to specify an epic for this new nation with such deep spatial and temporal affinities? I propose combining 'epical' textual strands for Bangladesh from two opposite directions. The first is the centuries-old body of homegrown folktales centered on all-sacrificing Muslim woman heroes (e.g. Roopban). This tale of Roopban, an adolescent peasant girl who had to marry as well as mother an ill-fated baby prince, has repeatedly been textualized in popular films, songs, and rural performances. The second strand concerns birthing tales of the nation, narrativizations of the 1971 war of liberation as portrayed in films, songs, novels, and paintings. Of exceptional importance here, as oral text for emergent Bangladesh, is the historic 7 March 1971 speech of Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, the ‘father of the nation’ who led (East) Bengalis in their war of liberation against the mighty Pakistani military junta. His 19-minute address marked a decisive moment in the last days of East Pakistan.  Millions of East Pakistanis gathered at Suhrawardy park in Dhaka to hear it (pictured), and it immediately became a watershed moment in Bangladesh history. The speech itself was recognized as a documentary heritage by UNESCO in 2017. By different routes and roots, then, these epic moments combine to form 'national' tales for Bangladesh, tapping deeply into the geo-cultural spirit of the land, the Bengal Delta.

properties.name: Brazil
properties.author: Caio Cesar Esteves de Souza (Harvard University)
properties.caption: Tarsila do Amaral, Antropofagia,’ 1929 (Wikiart)
properties.description: Since the early days of its colonization, Brazil has drawn the attention of other Western nations due to its diverse Indigenous populations and their cultures. It should come as no surprise that when nationalist authors in the 19th century took on the mission of building a literary identity for that young nation they chose to elaborate on the theme of encounters between Europeans and Indigenous peoples. Several 18th-century epic poems – such as O Uraguai (1769), and Caramuru (1781) – were regarded as precursors of their quest for a national identity, perceived as the product of the racial and cultural encounter between Portuguese and Indigenous populations along the coast of Brazil. A central figure of such a project, José de Alencar wrote at least three novels that could be figured as Brazilian national epics – O Guarani (1857), Iracema (1865), and Ubirajara (1874). Machado de Assis (1839-1808) would present an antithesis to that national project by considering the enslaved African presence in Brazilian society, thus drastically destabilizing that utopic biracial foundational myth. Modernist authors such as Mario de Andrade would, in the early 20th century, present some sort of synthesis to that project, considering those historical contradictions as part of Brazilian national identity in their own modern national epics, such as de Andrade's Macunaíma (1928). This entire historical narrative, however, itself forms a type of national epic on its own, one created in the mid-20th century by literary historiography to affix a meaning to ‘Brazil’. This chapter focusses on moments when authors employed literary form to understand what constitutes ‘Brazil’ as a working concept, and considers their critical reception. Our corpus ranges from the writings of José de Anchieta (1534-97) to those of Guimarães Rosa (1908-67).

properties.name: Sweden
properties.author: Jens Liljestrand (Stockholm)
properties.caption: Utvandrarna (The Emigrants, 1971, dir. Jan Troell)
properties.description: The topic of national epics in literature is complicated when it comes to Sweden. Swedish society and culture in the modern era, compared to other developed countries, is less focused on tradition and instead promotes values of solidarity, climate awareness, gender equality and globalization. Consequently, authors and poets admired as national icons in the past and revered for their idolizing of famous kings, like Georg Stiernhielm (1598-1672) or Esaias Tegnér (1782-1846), or then later Verner von Heidenstam (1859-1940), are rarely quoted outside classrooms. In fact, even reciting poems like Esaias Tegnérs ‘Svea’ has become a mark of right wing-extremism. Premodern expressions of national values in literature have thus often come to symbolize authoritarianism, values far outside the mainstream. The internationally most important Swedish author and playwright, August Strindberg (1849-1912), might arguably be considered a national writer-- but his work is generally too complex, experimental, delirious and steeped in misogyny to seamlessly be placed in that context. In today's Sweden, national identity is mostly woven into folk culture and its rich mixture of oral history, tall tales, comedy, romanticism and sometimes brutal realism. Selma Lagerlöf (1858-1940) is in that sense a prime example of a pre-1950 author with a claim to have touched upon the national identity of Sweden. Her masterpiece, Gösta Berlings saga (1891), may well be considered a prose epic of Swedish country life, telling the story of a defrocked minister finding his way in the province of Värmland in the 1820’s. The only work of literature, however, commonly referred to as a national epic of Sweden is The Emigrants, a quartet published 1949-1959 by Vilhelm Moberg (1898-1973). The novels tell of a peasant family emigrating to the USA and settling in Minnesota in the 1850s. Its themes of suffering, self-reliance, hard labor, loss and redemption touch both on the classical folk cultural aspects of Swedish national identity as well as its more modern strains of internationalism, multi-culturalism, individualism, and progressivity.

properties.name: Ecuador
properties.author: Juan Carlos G Mantilla (Columbia University)
properties.caption: Osvaldo Guayasamin, portrait of Atahualpa (1945)
properties.description: Amidst the heroes of the Independence wars from Spain, and the early national chieftains, the afterlives of the Shyris and of Atahualpa extend deeply into the earliest times of the smallest of the Andean nations. Though pre-Columbian, both the Shyris and Atahualpa have been nationalized as Ecuadorian and monumentalized as emblems of the Pre-Columbian substratum of Ecuadorian nationhood. The history of the Shyris, a Pre-Inca polity of Quito, is an archaeological fiction: a great society of the ancient Americas that never existed. Its rulers, the Caran and Duchicelas, were popularized in the late-18th century work of the Jesuit Juan de Velasco, Historia del Reino de Quito, drawn from previous sources, and transmitted into Ecuadorian national histories. The idea of a Pre-Inca polity of Quito, its heroes and princesses, served as an Ecuadorian counternarrative to accounts of the Andean Americas centered on the overarching presence of the Incas of Cuzco. The heroic figure of Atahualpa, the Inca captured and killed in Cajamarca by the  Spanish Conquerors in 1532, was imagined in Ecuadorian indigenist art and literature as “The Last Inca Emperor.” Artists and scholars argued that Atahualpa was born somewhere in the Ecuadorian territory and depicted him as the lawful heir of Inca rulership. Hero and martyr, Atahualpa served as a dynamic epic figure to create nationalist oppositions not only against Spanish colonialism but also against Peru, as represented by Atahualpa’s enemy and half-brother Huascar, an Inca from Cuzco. The driving force of Ecuadorian pre-Columbian epics depended on the oppositions vis-à-vis Peru: Shyris versus Incas, and Atahualpa the quiteño versus Huascar the cuzqueño. Ecuadorian nationalism developed in the context of the never-ending armed conflicts against Perú (from 1828 to 1995); Ecuadorians thus shaped such epics in sight of Peru, seen as a declared enemy and a constant threat to Ecuadorian borders and sovereignty.

properties.name: U.S.A
properties.author: Thadious M. Davis (University of Pennsylvania)
properties.caption: Gjackson22, CC BY-SA 4.0 via Wikimedia Commons
properties.description: From the re-naming of the United Colonies to the United States of America in 1776, the ever-evolving nation has witnessed recurrent efforts to forge a cohesive vision of a collective identity. Joel Barlow was among the first to attempt an epic about the young nation in Vision of Columbus (1787, expanded into The Columbiad, 1807) and in his mock epic, The Hasty-Pudding (1796), which celebrated ordinary fare and plain folk but aimed to create a national literature. Barlow’s work anticipated the ensuing drive for a memorable narrative centered in historical awareness and political consciousness that would inspire, enlighten, and engage readers with shared ideals and values. The result has been neither epicity in the traditional poetic sense nor one monumental national epic because no single endeavor has sustained relevancy over time. Successive generations of artists, writers, and musicians nevertheless have pursued creating an epic that would mark the history and collective past of a developing nation and the cultural expressivity and aesthetics of its changing present. This chapter explores those generational efforts and focuses on their culmination in the late twentieth and early twenty-first century. It follows the long aesthetic drive to this period and the embrace of multiple genres to narrativize a representative story. It posits Toni Morrison’s trilogy—Beloved (1987),  Jazz (1992), and Paradise (1998)— as espousing and encapsulating an innovative way forward in imagining and constituting U. S. epic-making. Her linguistic feats recall classic epic writers but connect experimental modernists to the merging of drama, music, and poetry in Lin-Manuel Miranda’s Hamilton: An American Musical (2015), which braids together theatre and vocal arts with hip-hop, rap, and spoken word to transform the modern stage and national history, so that an immigrant founding father’s individual story re-calibrates U. S. epic storytelling for the new century.

properties.name: Japan
properties.author: David Lurie (Columbia University)
properties.caption: Bakin's Hakkenden
properties.description: Rather than look for a single ‘national epic of Japan,’ this chapter compares multiple contenders for the honor. While ‘epic’ could be defined in rigorous formal terms (which if narrowly derived from Homer’s poems would likely lead to the conclusion that Japan has none), the ‘national’ brings in complex interactions between production and reception across a literary-historical longue durée. The first myth-histories, the early 8th century CE Kojiki (‘Record of Ancient Matters’) and Nihon shoki (“Chronicle of Japan”), narrated the establishment and perpetuation of the reigning imperial lineage from the cosmogonic creation of the Japanese archipelago down to annals of recent rulers. Over their long reception history both texts have been treated as ‘cultural encyclopedias’ and as epics of the emergence of the Japanese nation. The Tale of Genji (early 11th century), a long and psychologically perceptive story of court life that presents a kind of counter-narrative to the foregoing historical works (as explicitly proposed in a famous self-referential passage about the nature and purpose of fiction). The great war tales that coalesced in the 14th century, the Tale of the Heike and Taiheiki (‘Record of the Great Peace’), which narrated the fall of the Taira clan (and resulting rise of warrior rule) and a subsequent civil war that further weakened the court. These enormously popular works had outsize impact on many other genres, in much the same way that the Trojan War and its aftermath served as a fundamental story-world for ancient Greek literature. The two best-selling historical narratives of early modern Japan, Rai San'yō's nonfictional Nihon gaishi (‘Unofficial History of Japan’; completed 1827) and Kyokutei Bakin's fictional Hakkenden (‘Eight Dog Chronicle’; published 1814-1842), each of which aspired to be (and was to some extent treated as) a kind of new epic of the nation’s formation and ethos.

properties.name: Argentina
properties.author: Alejandro Quintero Mächler (Universidad Autónoma de México, UNAM)
properties.caption: Charles Henri Pellegrini, El matadero de Buenos Aires
properties.description: Since its posthumous publication in 1871, Esteban Echeverría’s El Matadero (1844) (‘The Slaughterhouse’ or ‘The Slaughter Yard’) has earned its rightful placed in the Argentinian canon, required reading in schools and colleges. Republished time and again, endlessly re-interpreted, meticulously analyzed, it has managed to remain significant and somewhat elusive for more than a century. A problematic, genre-defying text suffused with bloody, shocking symbolism, El Matadero established an enduring image of Juan Manuel de Rosas’ regime (1829-1852) at a defining historical moment when ‘Argentina,’ famed for its raising and canning of cattle, was undergoing a violent, traumatic, and still undecided nation-building process. By bringing together manifold elements of Rosas’ political project and synthethizing them in the powerful image of the slaughterhouse, Echeverría successfully linked repressive State violence with national character, an emotional regime with meat-eating habits, and the growing menace of barbarism with the cattle-ranching, export-based economic system espoused by the regime. El Matadero was not created in a cultural vacuum, but represents the most renowned iteration of  highly controversial imagery which was widely utilized by both detractors and supporters of Rosas’ regime: the tip of a literary iceberg obsessed with the slaughterhouse’s aptness to encapsulate the true meaning of the nation. This metaphor, consequently, was not Echeverría’s exclusive property: it was ubiquitous, on the one hand, in the Anti-rosista literature produced by the romantic Generación del 37 while in exile; and it was frequently used, on the other, by the Rosistas themselves to advance their populist values and their ‘Americanist’ banners. Omnipresent in periodicals, essays, novels, articles, libels, pamphlets, poems, even oil paintings and lithographs, the slaughterhouse belonged to a wide, shared, yet contested political language whose power and efficacy would prove long-lasting in both print and visual culture in Argentina.

properties.name: Canada
properties.author: Sarah Wylie Krotz (University of Alberta)
properties.caption: View of Purbrook in Medonte Township, Upper Canada (1836)
properties.description: The earliest national epics of Canada are tied to its settler-colonial history. These narratives focus on the chief obstacle, and desire, of the thousands of emigrants who ‘swarmed’ the shores through the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries: land – mistakenly perceived as impossibly vast and untamed. They dramatize the imperial heroics of exploring, appropriating, and transforming forests, grasslands, and shorelines into farms, towns, and cities, and unifying the territory ‘from Sea to Sea’ (as the nation’s motto goes). But they only tell one side of Canada’s story. My discussion will range across not one, but many threads that unravel a singular ‘epic’ past, and point to Canada’s tangled and contested origins. I will address not only the aspirational heroics of nation building that long occupied a central place in Canadian epic imaginaries, but also the counter-narratives that challenge both the unity and heroism toward which epic points. E.J. Pratt, whose long poem Towards the Last Spike (1952) came to be regarded by many as Canada’s national epic, hinged the nation’s story on the arduous construction of the Canadian Pacific Railroad that unified the country mere days before the Métis leader Louis Riel was hanged. Pratt’s poem exemplifies the ways heroic narratives conceal other stories: of those who were displaced, abused, disenfranchised, even slain, in the name of colonial expansion and ‘progress.’ Alongside Pratt and forerunners like Susanna Moodie (Roughing It in the Bush) and Charles Mair (‘The Last Bison’), contemporary poets and storytellers such as George Elliott Clarke (Canticles), Leanne Betasamosake Simpson (Noopiming: The Cure for White Ladies), Tasha Hubbard (Buffalo Calling), and Trevor Herriot (Towards a Prairie Atonement) call attention to the other worlds – of Imperialism and slavery; of Indigenous relationships to land, healing, and resurgence; of lost ecological community – that lead us through grief to renewal.

properties.name: Croatia
properties.author: Ivan Lupić (Stanford University), Luka Špoljarić (University of Zagreb)
properties.caption: Marko Marulić, The History of the Holy Widow Judith Composed in Croatian Verse (Venice: Bernardino Benalio, 1522), title page
properties.description: Upon finishing his Croatian epic Judita (Judith) early in 1501, Marko Marulić (1450–1524) composed an elaborate dedicatory epistle to his friend Dujam Balistrilić, identifying two equally important models for his novel literary undertaking: the poetic work of his anonymous vernacular predecessors and the tradition of classical epic.  Marulić's choice of Judith was hardly an accident: for as the Ottomans aggressively assaulted the walls of Marulić’s native Split, the story of how the beautiful widow Judith saved her city of Bethulia from Assyrian siege by seducing and killing general Holofernes lent itself to suggestive allegorical reading. Marulić styled himself the Croatian Dante, and the proliferation of early editions, all published in Venice (1521, 1522, 1523), proved him right. Judita's centrality to Croatian literary tradition was confirmed by new editions in 1586 and 1627, but also by later epic poets, who adopted from Marulić the model of the Christian poet responding to the historical fortunes of his people. The most spectacular example is Osman, the unfinished masterpiece of the Dubrovnik poet Ivan Gundulić (1589–1638) that circulated widely in manuscript before being printed in the early 19th century. While the movement for Croatian national revival at first recognized Gundulić as the author of the true national epic, by the late 19th century it was Marulić who, thanks primarily to Judita, became definitively established as ‘the father of Croatian literature.’ 22 April, the day when Marulić composed his dedicatory epistle to Balistrilić, is today officially celebrated as the Day of the Croatian Book. Marulić’s survival in national consciousness greatly depends, however, on his place in the national curriculum, now subject to question. And among readers, Judita shares the fate of other great national epics: it is demanding, designed to be read slowly and attentively, and thus ill-suited to the habits of new, digitally-conditioned generations.

properties.name: Turkey
properties.author: Arzu Öztürkmen (Boğaziçi University)
properties.caption: A scene from the performance of folk minstrel (Aşık/Ozan) Murat Çobanoğlu (1940-2005), known for his collection of the Kiziroğlu Mustafa Bey story from Köroğlu epic
properties.description: The concept of national epic (Milli destan) is complex in Turkey, approached differently by various academic communities. When the Republic of Turkey was founded in 1923, two threads of cultural ideology prevailed, one inspired by Turkism, rooted in the late Ottoman era, the other by Republican desire to construct Anatolia as a new national space.  As opposed to Pan-Turkism, Republican nationalism adopted a territorial approach, with Anatolia as homeland (home to diverse Turkic epics). Both threads were later transferred to centralized national education, where the term ‘Turkish’ embedded both Turkic and Anatolian components.  The concept of ‘Turkish epics’ therefore comprises multiple genres. Oğuznames, the Turkic epic manuscripts, include the heroic founding myths of Turks in Central Asia before their conversion to Islam. The Book of Dede Korkut is seen to survive from the first settlement of the Oğuz tribes in Anatolia.  The widespread genre of gazavatname, manuscripts of epic narratives on Islamic history, tell of wars or conquests during the Ottoman period. Many of these likely formed part of a strong oral storytelling tradition. Köroğlu Destanı, one of best examples, tells of a rebel against the Ottoman Sultan. Although epic romances have been categorized as ‘folk stories’ (halk hikayeleri), the genre was widely told by meddahs, travelling storytellers (performing particularly in coffeehouses). Minstrel performing of epic narratives continued during the Republican era, both provincially and on national media, and epic narratives still feature as graphic novellas, popular movies, and TV series. Despite increasing research on epic traditions both in Anatolia and Turkish-speaking lands of former Soviet Union countries after the 1990s, examining the notion of ‘national epic’ in Turkey still requires further articulation of a complex historical ethnography.

properties.name: Vietnam
properties.author: Nguyen Nguyet Cam & Peter Zinoman (University of California, Berkeley)
properties.description: Nationalists often disagree about which literary text best expresses the soul of their nation.  But approaches to this question by Vietnamese nationalists have been unusually one-sided, marked by a durable, near unanimous consensus that the obvious national epic is The Tale of Kieu, Nguyen Du’s early 19th-century verse narrative about the turbulent fate of an elite beauty sold into prostitution to liquidate a catastrophic family debt.  The stable consensus about The Tale of Kieu’s nationalist status requires some explanation, especially given the poem’s putatively ‘low’ subject matter and the disruptive and divisive impact on the country’s modern history of colonial rule, communist revolution, civil war, and American intervention.  While the Vietnamese political community has been bitterly divided on a huge range of issues through much of the 20th century, few have disputed Pham Quynh’s famous statement from 1924: ‘As long as The Tale of Kieu survives, our language survives; as long as our language survives, our nation survives.’  This chapter explores the history of The Tale of Kieu’s elevation to the status of national epic – a story of the successful invention of a national tradition by a small group of Vietnamese cultural activists during the late-colonial decade of the 1920s.  But it also sheds light on the conundrum of why the text has retained its singular aura for one hundred years as a fundamental source of national identity for Vietnamese living under radically different political regimes.  To address this issue, the essay will examine evidence about the warm reception of the poem among Vietnamese audiences prior to the nationalist era.  It will also consider thematic, poetic, and narrative features of the text that have contributed to its appeal for nationalist activists of different political stripes as well as its enduring popularity with the reading public.

properties.name: Estonia
properties.author: Cornelius Hasselblatt (Estonian Academy of Sciences)
properties.caption: Oskar Kallis, Kalevipoeg laudu kandmas (1914), Wikimedia Commons
properties.description: ‘Let us give the people an epic and a history and everything is won!’ – exclaimed the Baltic German physician and Estophile Georg Schultz-Bertram when addressing the recently founded Learned Estonian Society in 1839 at Tartu (then a university town in the Governorate of Livonia of the Russian Empire). But what has to be ‘won’, and what was ‘lost’? The area on the northeastern shores of the Baltic sea inhabited by Estonians had been conquered by German and Danish knights in the 13th century, and then later governed by Teutonic knights, and then by Denmark, Sweden, Poland and Russia (while local power remained  in the hands of the German nobility). During the 19th century, however, Estonians increasingly wished to emancipate themselves from serfdom (which formally was abolished in 1816/1819) and foreign control. Having witnessed publication of the Finnish Kalevala in 1835, leading intellectuals longed for an equivalent in Estonian (closely related to Finnish, and partly sharing the same folklore). It was the physician Friedrich Reinhold Kreutzwald (1803–1882) who in the 1850s compiled from ancient tales about the hero Kalevipoeg (‘The Son of Kalev’) an epic consisting of 19,033 trochaic verses. But he faced serious problems with censorship, and so ‘disguised’ the text as a scholarly edition accompanied by a German translation (appearing in the Proceedings of the Learned Estonian Society, 1857-61). This had hardly any impact on the average Estonian reader, and the monolingual popular edition from 1862 still did not really reach its audience. Only in the 1880s did a first generation of Estonian students start  thoroughly to read the poem, and to make it ‘their own, national epic’. Since then, the Kalevipoeg has become a core text of Estonian letters, and is continuously being reread, quoted, adapted and diffused throughout all areas of Estonian art and society.

properties.name: Suriname
properties.author: Michiel van Kempen (University of Amsterdam)
properties.description: Anton de Kom’s only book, We Slaves of Suriname, published in 1934 in Dutch, was way ahead of its time. A child of parents who had suffered from slavery, De Kom (pictured) became the first black historian of his country, radically changing the image of four centuries of Dutch colonial history. His book is a literary masterpiece, telling heartbreaking stories of how Surinamese people survived the era of slavery, and then struggled afterwards to overcome the old slave mentality. From the late 19th century, contract labourers were sailed in from China, British India, and Java and put to work on the plantations, their living conditions hardly better than those of the enslaved. Anton de Kom wrote down their stories, but was banished by the colonial authorities in 1933. Inspired by the anticolonial words of his fellow-countryman Albert Helman, writer of the first modern Dutch slavery novel, Anton de Kom started to write his Wij slaven van Suriname, publishing it long before other rewritings of Caribbean history such as The Black Ja¬co¬bins by C.L.R. James, on the Haïtian revolution, or Trinadadian Eric Williams’ thesis Capi¬ta¬lism and Slavery. Suriname is situated on the north-east coast of Latin-America, but considered to be a Caribbean country-- historically, culturally, economically. Its vast area of Amazonian rainforest hosts relatively few people, from four continents, each bringing distinctive cultures and speaking over 22 languages. It was a colony, a settlement, and it was only after World War II that it became something like one nation. It has been said that it was not the politicians but the great Surinamese poets like Trefossa, Michael Slory, and Shrinivási who realized Surinamese independence in the year 1975. They too were inspired by the expressive power of We Slaves of Suriname. Anton de Kom’s book was published in English translation only in 2022.

properties.name: Netherlands
properties.author: Lotte E. Jensen (Radboud University, Nijmegen)
properties.caption: De Hollandsche natie (1870 edition)
properties.description: In 1812 De Hollandsche natie by Jan Frederik Helmers was published, a poetic national epic which argued for Dutch superiority over all other nations in the field of war, the maritime sector, and arts and sciences. His work, full of anti-French sentiments, also reads as a fierce statement against Napoleonic occupation. Helmer’s poem sees the protagonist not as a particular hero, but as the entire Dutch nation. Helmers was clearly inspired by other well-known epics, such as Virgil’s Aeneid and especially Os Lusíadas (1572) by Luis de Camões. By rewriting some fragments of Camões’ poem, Helmers intended to show that the Dutch sea conquerors were superior to the Portuguese. He also derived inspiration from La Henriade (1728) by Voltaire about Henry IV of France. Helmers was also indebted to several 18th-century Dutch epic poems about founders of the fatherland. Examples are Friso (1741) by Willem van Haren, Germanicus (1779) by Lucretia van Merken, Willem de Eerste (1779) by Johannes Nomsz, and M.A. de Ruyter (1784) by Adriaan Loosjes. Their choices of specific ‘founding fathers’ were widely discussed by critics. The poem De Geusen (1771), a collection of Dutch heroic events and persons by Onno Zwier van Haren, can also be seen as a forerunner of Helmer’s poem. Due to nationalist tendencies, however, Helmer’ poem became an instant classic and would be considered the first true national epic in Dutch literary history. Meanwhile, 19th-century scholars searched for older national literary roots in the archives and came up with several texts, such as Reinaert de Vos and Karel ende Elegast. Reinaert de Vos, originally written in the 13th century, became the flagship of Dutch literature, but was also claimed to be of German, Flemish, and French origin. Nowadays, these poems are still widely read in secondary schools, while Helmer’s nationalist verses have fallen out of fashion entirely.

properties.name: Albania
properties.author: Rigels Halili (University of Warsaw)
properties.caption: Skanderbeg's monument in the main Tirana's main square (RH)
properties.description: Various poems could aspire to the role of Albanian national epic, but two are widely recognized as such: Istori e Skënderbeut (The History of Skanderbeg) by Naim Frashëri (1846-1900), and Lahuta e Malcis’ (The Highland Lute) by Gjergj Fishta OFM (1981-1940). Naim Frashëri is widely perceived as the main poet of the Albanian National Movement, along with his brothers Abdyl and Sami. The History of Skanderbeg belongs to his later works and was seen by the poet as his opus vitae. The poem's 11500 verses follow the life and deeds of Gjergj (George) Kastrioti (1405-1468), known as Skënderbej (Skanderbeg). Naim based his poem mainly on a historical account by the priest Marinus Barletius (c. 1450-c.1513) and used the octosyllabic verse (typical for southern Albanian oral epic and lyric poetry. Skanderbeg appears in this poem as Albania's uncrowned king, a righteous knight beloved by God who opposes (but not fanatically) the Ottoman invasion. Naim turned the 15th century knight into a leading figure of modern Albanian nationalism. Fishta began to publish cantos from his poem in 1907, with the final edition appearing only in 1937 as 17000 lines of octosyllabic verse. Contrary to Naim, who made Skanderbeg a national hero, Fishta chose to tell stories from the Albanian-Montenegrin rivalry of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, transforming local figures into national heroes: common folk who oppose their lands being taken or partitioned, who believe in God, but also seek help from traditional mountains and forests spirits, or zanas (the Albanian name for female fairies living up in the mountains). Like Naim, Fishta created an epic world, an ideal space identifiable in time and space while yet standing as an ideal model for national identity.

properties.name: Algeria
properties.author: Jill Jarvis (Yale University)
properties.caption: Mohamed Issiakhem, Les aveugles
properties.description: This chapter focuses—perhaps surprisingly, given the enormous archive of literary works that figure (or disfigure) Algeria’s national epic—on a single novel by the relatively obscure writer Yamina Mechakra entitled La grotte éclatée (the shattered cave). It will discuss the linguistic multiplicity present in the French-language text; will reflect on the novel’s Arabic translations and transmissions; and will bring Mechakra’s text into contact with a series of literary, visual, theatrical, and cinematic works by Kateb Yacine, Assia Djebar, Abdelhamid Benhedouga, and Mohamed Issiakhem—whose painting Les aveugles Mechakra chose for the cover of her novel’s second edition. Composed a decade after Algeria’s hard-fought independence from French colonial occupation in 1962, Mechakra’s novel at first reads like eyewitness first-person testimony of the anticolonial war (1954-1962). At the novel’s midpoint, what at first read as soldier testimony (a monumentalized and epic genre in postcolonial Algeria) is violently shattered and transfigured into something else entirely. This chapter reflects on the unsettling way that Mechakra’s text reworks Algeria’s national epic in fragmented, incomplete, and tragic forms. La grotte éclatée is closely connected to Algerian histories, sensibilities, languages, and terrains; it assumes an almost visceral intimacy with Algerian nationalism, and also alludes to histories of collective indigenous resistance that long predate French, Ottoman, and Arab conquests and colonizations. Mechakra’s text draws on the aesthetic resources of both Greek tragedy and a repertoire of Chaoui and Mozabite song and storytelling practice that she claims equally as her ‘ancestral orality.’ In particular, La grotte éclatée channels and amplifies legends of an icon of Amazigh anticolonial resistance known as the Kahena. The chapter reflects closely on the heterogeneous archive constructed through Mechakra’s subversive intertextual poetics in order to consider crucial tensions between postcolonial Algerian nationalism and contemporary Amazigh indigeneities.

properties.name: Lithuania
properties.author: Mikas Vaicekauskas (Institute of Lithuanian Literature and Folklore)
properties.caption: Kristijonas Donelaitis 300th birth anniversary stamp
properties.description: During the period of Lithuanian national revival in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, when Lithuania lived under Russian imperial occupation, national literature in the native language was of particular importance for forming Lithuanian national identity. But despite a few earlier, exceptional instances, Lithuanian literature was only just beginning to evolve towards  creating a national cultural field. A national epic could have proved foundational for developing cultural consciousness, but Lithuanians did not have one. And so many poets set out to identify or create home-grown national epics, while others sought to adapt literary works from neighbouring or related cultures. None of these proved satisfactory. In the later 20th century, philologists, ethnologists, and historians tried to find, or to reconstruct, the national epic, detecting alleged epical traces in traditional folk songs, in historical chronicles, or in Renaissance or Baroque heroic poems in Latin. Again, this was not convincing. More recently, the narrative poem Metai (The Seasons), composed between 1765 and 1775 by Kristijonas Donelaitis, a Lutheran priest living in the Kingdom of Prussia, has come to be considered as a possible national epic. Donelaitis is now unanimously regarded as Lithuania's first national poet, and his Metai as an unsurpassed national poetic work. Metai was not earlier unknown or suppressed, but was not apprehended as a national epic. The poem tells of peasants’ daily and seasonal lives, or of the totality of life, and does  features some of the essential properties of classical epic: versification (hexameter), artistic devices (hyperbole, etc.), lexical features, speeches and dialogues, catalogues, a leaning towards absolutisation, moral imperatives, didacticism, God-given order, and the idea of cyclical time. Modern cultural consciousness can thus, retrospectively, regard Metai as the national epic that was so much needed in the years when national identity or national spirit was taking shape.

properties.name: Slovenia
properties.author: Marko Juvan (Research Center of the Slovenian Academy of Sciences and Arts, Ljubljana)
properties.caption: Hinko Smrekar (1883-1942 [shot dead as a hostage by fascists during WWII]), 'Krst pri Savici', published in Življenje in svet, 1936, no. 15.
properties.description: In his Byronic verse-tale Baptism on the Savica (Krst pri Savici, 1836), the Slovenian poet France Prešeren (1800–49) depicts the downfall of an epic hero who is forced to renounce the destroyed proto-national community of Slavic peoples and submit to supranational and victorious Christianity. Prešeren’s theme, taken from Carniolan historiography, is the defeat of the uprising of the pagan Alpine Slavs against the Christian army in the eighth century, during which they lost their cultural and political autonomy. Baptism on the Savica is thus about the medieval origin of the “unhistorical” status of the modern nation, which aspired to autonomy within the Habsburg Empire. The invention of the catastrophic founding myth, which called for a national resurrection through cultural emancipation, served the needs of the 19th-century Slovenian national movement. Based on cultural nationalism, Baptism became a national epic not only because it corresponded to Schlegel’s concept of the Nationalgedicht or Heldengedicht (i.e., an individualized story against a world-historical background), but also thanks to its sophisticated esthetic features. Baptism uses topoi and forms of ancient, medieval, and post-Renaissance epic poetry and crosses them with the contemporary genre of Byronic ‘metrical tales.’ Moreover, Prešeren mixes epic narrative with elegiac lyricism, through which he identifies with his protagonist. The second part of the poem, a strongly individualized story of love, existential crisis, and renunciation, resembles the bourgeois genres of drama or novel. Baptism is a national epic, albeit constructed with deliberate ambivalence. As such, it entered the literary canon towards the end of the 19th century. Compared to Prešeren’s undisputed status as a ‘national poet,’ Baptism became a point of ideological-esthetic contention. It repeatedly evoked conflicting interpretations, intertextual references, derivations, and reductive uses in public discourse.

properties.name: England
properties.author: David Wallace (University of Pennsylvania
properties.caption: University of Pennsylvania, MS Roll 1066 (membrane 7 side 1, c. 1461), successors to King Arthur
properties.description: Repeated attempts have been made to write, to define, the national epic of England. Inconclusiveness might be regarded not as failure, but as work in progress. England long developed vibrant local literatures in a language of scant global resonance. Then, through the 19th century, English went global. England withdrew from European ground after 1558, intensifying insular self-definition while expanding its reach through sea-lanes. Rejoining Europe in 1973, England withdrew again in 2016, dragging the rest of the UK with it, in search of imperium lost. Bede offers a foundational account gentis Anglorum, but as ecclesiastical history, and in Latin. Geoffrey of Monmouth's Latin History of the Kings of Britain becomes foundational to chronicling, and brings King Arthur to prominence. But once Camelot dissolves, claimants to hegemony again proliferate, in multiple strands (see above). Beowulf, a poem about Danes first edited by a Dane, was studied compulsorily in the Oxford English tripos throughout the 20th century; the Song of Roland, whose best manuscript is in Anglo-Norman, and resides at Oxford, was not. Following the Reformation, new ancient epics address new English times. Spenser, in Ireland, wrote his Faerie Queen, Milton (having pondered an Arthuriad) his Paradise Lost, and Blake his prophetic books. All proved too idiosyncratic to stick as national epics, and in the 1930s Tolkien (while promoting Beowulf) was still seeing an opening for a national epic: one of his own invention. The real life epic of colonial subjects enlisted to fight for England, in two world wars, remained largely unwritten as warriors were repatriated, to Kingston or Delhi, once war was done. Their descendants are now, finally, writing their own versions of agon in England, on English ground. And through all this, one textual corpus continually evolves its time-honored function as England's national epic.

properties.name: Mali
properties.author: Jan Jansen (Leiden University)
properties.caption: Mansa Musa, king of Mali, in 1375 'Catalan Atlas' by Jafuda Cresques
properties.description: Medieval Arab scholars had much to say about ‘Mali’, a rich West African kingdom. Some report that Mali’s ruler gains authority by being descended lauded from Sunjata. Nowadays Sunjata still features in West African oral traditions and standardized praise songs; Jata means ‘lion’, and the fascination for this animal has been key to Sunjata’s wide appeal over the centuries. Literary scholars have assessed the oral traditions featuring Sunjata as ‘epic’, and historians have unveiled historical aspects of these traditions, ranging from iron age practices to processes of state formation in modern times. However, the Sunjata epic draws its great present-day fame, and it claims to be counted among ‘national epics,’ from early 20th-century scholarship that attributed to medieval Mali the status of ‘empire,’ and that ‘humanized’ Sunjata as a 13th-century, historical founder of the dynasty of Mali’s rulers. This ‘history’ (not meeting present-day research standards) was taught as complementary to an (equally biased) linear history of France – narrated in terms of empires and nations – to West African schoolteachers. This account became commonly accepted among the political elites of the independence era, and so medieval Mali (and Sunjata) became historical sources of inspiration for French colonies seeking independence. This is best illustrated by Soudan Français becoming ‘République du Mali’ in 1960. This image of the historical person Sunjata as founder of the Mali empire has since been further rooted in society by classroom teaching, theatre plays, popular music, movies, novels, and other media. An important recent development is the growing public tendency to view Sunjata’s foundation of society as a charter representing Africa’s contribution to the Declaration of Universal Human Rights, thus transcending intellectually Western biases in Human Rights thinking and thus empowering West Africa’s role in global history.

properties.name: Chile
properties.author: Maxwell Samuel Woods (Universidad Adolfo Ibáñez, Chile) and Stefanie Massman Wyneken (Universidad Andrés Bello, Chile)
properties.caption: caption: Raymond Monvoisin (1790-1870), death of toqui Caupolicán (1558)
properties.description: From the earliest epic of Chile’s history, The Araucaniad (1569-1589) by Alonso de Ercilla, to contemporary epic graffiti murals depicting Chile’s history, like Danny Reveco’s Without Land, without Water, without Sky (2017), a common thread running through Chile’s epic tradition has been the incorporation, negation, elimination, heroization, infantilization, eulogization, resistance, and persistence of the Indigenous nations living within the borders of what has become Chilean national territory. As a result, these Chilean epics have had to confront the violence and spoliation attending the nation’s foundation. This epic thread begins with colonial-era representations of the conquest like Ercilla’s The Araucaniad (1569, 1578, 1589) and Pedro de Oña’s Arauco Tamed (1596) that face the problem of how to represent Indigenous nations and Spanish colonial military commanders during the conquest as well as Chile’s peripheral position within the Spanish empire. Later, in the century and a half following the formation of the Chilean nation-state in the early 19th century, authors like Alberto Blest Gana and Gabriela Mistral were frequently concerned with the consolidation of the Chilean nation, a task requiring the imagined incorporation or erasure of Indigenous nations within a singular Chilean nationality as well as a reckoning with that imagined Chilean nationality’s dependence on and peripheral relationship to European cultural, political, and economic dominance. Lastly, in the late 20th and early 21st centuries, authors and artists like Nona Fernández and Danny Reveco presented renewed focus on the spoliation and violence waged against Indigenous nations throughout Chilean history, thereby giving way to a new vision of plurinationality constituted by a multiplicity of autonomous nations and communities. In sum, the epic tradition in Chile has had to confront the (proto-/pluri-) nation’s incorporation or negation of Indigenous nations, its history of violence, and its peripheral condition.

properties.name: South Africa
properties.author: Rita Barnard (University of Pennsylvania)
properties.description: Key terms at stake in this volume, ‘nation’ and ‘epic,’ are especially productive and problematic for South Africa. Is South Africa a nation? Can there be any sort of foundational epic in a multilingual settler colony—a colony, moreover, whose history can be seen as one of competing nationalisms?  And what is an epic?  Should emphasis lie on the oral or the narrative implications of the term?  This contribution will examine Shaka ka Senzangakhona’s praise song (izibongo) as the most obvious example of the genre.
